title: Spelling
description: Canadian spelling conventions and common errors

content.text: Spelling poses a major problem in English because it is not phonetic and because the rules that can be formulated nearly always have significant exceptions. In addition, there are hundreds of words that have variant spellings in different parts of the English-speaking world, the principal cleavage being between the United Kingdom and the United States. Partly as a result of our historical links with Britain and our proximity to the United States, Canadian spelling has tended to waver between the forms used in these two countries, so that, to this day, there is no clearly established Canadian standard.

patterns.note: British spelling also makes a distinction between licence (noun), license (verb) and practice (noun), practise (verb); American uses license and practice for both forms.

keyPrinciple.title: Canadian Standard - Gage Canadian Dictionary
keyPrinciple.content: The recommended spelling authority is the Gage Canadian Dictionary, since it reflects the usage of most federal government departments and agencies more closely than do the Webster's or Oxford dictionaries, is based on research into Canadian usage, and contains specifically Canadian terms. When it lists two spellings for a word in the same entry, choose the one entered first. When two spellings are given separate entries, choose the primary spelling, which is the one followed by the definition (the variant simply refers the reader to the primary spelling entry). For scientific and technical words not in Gage, check Webster's Third New International Dictionary.

recommendedSpellings.title: Recommended Canadian Spelling Patterns
patterns: Single l (as in instil, not instill)
Single l in words such as enrolment (not enrolLment)
Double l in travelled, etc. (not traveled)
Use e for digraphs (exceptions: aesthetic and onomatopoeic)

warningBox.title: Respect U.S. Institution Names
warningBox.content: Respect the official spelling of names of U.S. institutions, e.g. Department of Defense, Center for Disease Control.

content.note: The important point with respect to spelling is to be consistent in your written work unless a good reason exists for using variant or archaic spellings.

content.text: Spell-checking functions are now included in word-processing programs for use with computers. They can help you eliminate, at the proofreading stage, most of the spelling and typographical errors in a document. Especially useful are the 'search' feature, which can instantly locate a specific combination of letters, and the 'search-and-replace' feature, which can find all instances of a misspelled word or variant spelling and replace them with the correct or preferred form.

drawbacks.title: Spell-checking Program Drawbacks
points: They cannot detect omissions of words.

They do not flag correctly spelled words that are incorrect in the specific context. Thus the sentence 'Ewe bake two manly arrows.' would be approved by a spell-checker for a sentence that should read 'You make too many errors.'
Unless they are part of a larger grammar-checking utility, they do not identify words that are grammatically wrong. Thus the sentence 'He do not understands.' would not be flagged.
They may not respect the spelling preferences of your organization or your clients. In this case, you can usually modify the content of the spell-checker dictionary.
The search-and-replace feature can result in misspellings that have to be reversed manually.

searchReplaceExample.title: Search-and-Replace Pitfall Example
searchReplaceExample.text: For example, you may have decided to use the spelling honour instead of honor, the variant listed in American spell-checker dictionaries. Instructing the spell-checker to make a universal change will affect even correctly spelled words such as honorarium, honorific and honorary as well as words placed in quotes or followed by [sic].
searchReplaceExample.solution: To avoid the error, give the command <space>honor<space> instead of just honor. A variation of this command is required to cover specific occurrences such as honor followed by a period.

prefixRules.title: Prefix Vowel Retention Rules
prefixRules.text: In two cases the final vowel of a unit prefix is omitted: megohm and kilohm. In other cases where the unit name begins with a vowel, both vowels are retained.

meterVsMetre.title: Meter vs. Metre
meterVsMetre.content: Note that meter is the spelling for a measuring device, while metre is the unit of length.

pluralForms.title: Identical Singular and Plural Forms
pluralForms.content: Note also that the singular and plural of the following unit names are identical: hertz, lux and siemens.

content.text: Many words are misspelled because they are confused with similar-sounding and similarly spelled words which, in fact, have a different meaning. content.text: The jingle 'i before e except after c or when sounded as a as in neighbour and weigh' covers the rule.

keyPrinciple.title: The i before e Rule
keyPrinciple.content: Write i before e, except after c, or when sounded as 'a' as in neighbour and weigh.

content.text: There is no basic rule for these endings. However, if there is a corresponding word ending in ation, the ending is usually able or ative; if the corresponding word ends in sion or tion not preceded by a, the ending is usually ible or itive:

sections.title: Final Consonants Doubled Before a Suffix

rule1.title: One-Syllable Words
rule1.text: Double the final consonant before y or before a suffix beginning with a vowel in a word of one syllable that ends in a single consonant preceded by a single vowel:

exceptions1.title: Exceptions - Long Vowel Sound
exceptions1.text: Do not double the final consonant in a word of one syllable if the vowel sound is long:

busNote.title: Special Note on 'bus'
busNote.content: Note that the preferred plural spelling of the noun bus is buses.

rule2.title: Multi-Syllable Words
rule2.text: The final consonant is doubled in words of more than one syllable ending in a single consonant preceded by a single vowel, if the accent is on the last syllable and the suffix begins with a vowel:

exceptions2.title: Special Cases
exceptions2.content: Note that there is no doubling of the consonant in targeted and benefited.

sections.title: Words Ending in a Silent e

rule1.title: Before Suffix Beginning with Vowel
rule1.text: The final e is usually dropped before a suffix beginning with a vowel:

cAndGRule.title: After c or g
cAndGRule.text: However, when e follows c or g it is retained before the vowels a and o to preserve the soft sound of these consonants:

distinctions.title: Retained e for Distinction
distinctions.text: Note that the e is retained even before i in some cases in order to distinguish a word from a similarly spelled one or to preserve a particular pronunciation:

rule2.title: Before Suffix Beginning with Consonant
rule2.text: Words ending in a silent e generally retain the e before a suffix beginning with a consonant:

eOptional.title: Optional e Retention
eOptional.content: Abridgment, acknowledgment and judgment can be spelled with or without the e, but the preferred spelling is as given (without the e).
